Title: tsvector @@ tsquery
Description: Does tsvector match tsquery? (The arguments can be given in either order.)
Examples: to_tsvector('fat cats ate rats') @@ to_tsquery('cat & rat') → t

Title: text @@ tsquery
Description: Does text string, after implicit invocation of to_tsvector(), match tsquery?
Examples: 'fat cats ate rats' @@ to_tsquery('cat & rat') → t

Title: tsvector @@@ tsquery
Description: This is a deprecated synonym for @@.
Examples: to_tsvector('fat cats ate rats') @@@ to_tsquery('cat & rat') → t

Title: tsvector || tsvector
Description: Concatenates two tsvectors. If both inputs contain lexeme positions, the second input's positions are adjusted accordingly.

Title: tsquery && tsquery
Description: ANDs two tsquerys together, producing a query that matches documents that match both input queries.

Title: tsquery || tsquery
Description: ORs two tsquerys together, producing a query that matches documents that match either input query.

Title: !! tsquery
Description: Negates a tsquery, producing a query that matches documents that do not match the input query.

Title: tsquery <-> tsquery
Description: Constructs a phrase query, which matches if the two input queries match at successive lexemes.

Title: tsquery @> tsquery
Description: Does first tsquery contain the second? (This considers only whether all the lexemes appearing in one query appear in the other, ignoring the combining operators.)

Title: tsquery <@ tsquery
Description: Is first tsquery contained in the second? (This considers only whether all the lexemes appearing in one query appear in the other, ignoring the combining operators.)
